div.p: Pupil of Hans Weisse and Heinrich Schenker.

div.head: Career Summary
div.p: In Vienna, Trude Kral was a piano pupil of Anka Bernstein Landau, the assistant of Richard Robert. She emigrated to the United States, where she joined the piano faculty of the Third Street Music School in New York.

div.head: Kral and Schenker
div.p: Trude Kral studied with Hans Weisse from probably as early as 1924 (when under his encouragement she took out a subscription to Schenker's Der Tonwille: OC 52/651). In 1925 she was living on the Langegasse, in the 8th district of Vienna (Josefstadt). After Weisse's emigration to the United States in summer 1931, she became a pupil of Schenker himself. It is not surprising that there is no mention of her in the latter's lessonbooks, since they end at August 14, 1931. At the start of the 1931/32 season, she became a member of Schenker's "Friday seminar" with Greta Kraus, Felix Salzer, and Manfred Willfort. She was not present at the first four meetings of the seminar (Oct 9–Nov 6), but is named in his informal notes as involved in the meeting on November 13 ("Kral III begins"), specifically in connection with the J. S. Bach C-major Prelude, Well-tempered Clavier, Book I, which would later appear as the first item of the Fünf Urlinie-Tafeln (1932).

As to the 1932/33 season, a conversation between Kral and Schenker is recorded in the latter's diary at OJ 4/5, p. 3775, September 22, 1932, which Schenker reported to Salzer in a letter of the same date (FS 40/1, [13]), concerning seminar plans for the new season. Kral did not attend the opening meetings, and finally gave notice of withdrawal on November 7 (OJ 4/6, p. 3789).

div.head: Correspondence
div.p: Two pieces of correspondence between Kral and Schenker are known to survive, one letter from her to Schenker (OC 30/40, December 31, 1932), and one fragmentary draft of a letter from Schenker to Kral (OC 30/41, undated).
